Synset.Definition: the relation of an owner to the thing possessed; possession with the right to transfer possession to others

Synset.ILIDefinition: a reserve created by a company for both expected and unexpected expenses; not distributable as dividends.

Synset.ILIDefinition: speculative dealing in stock exchange securities or foreign exchange.

Synset.Definition: the price for a good or service, less any sales tax or VAT the buyer pays and plus any subsidy the seller receives.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the price for a good or service, less any sales tax or VAT the buyer pays and plus any subsidy the seller receives.
Synset.Example: Even though the basic price was established a decade ago, some of our business partners want to raise it.

Synset.Definition: a price dictated by any entity other than market forces.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a price dictated by any entity other than market forces.

Synset.Definition: the costs that arise from the products/services not conforming to the requirements.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the costs that arise from the products/services not conforming to the requirements.
Synset.Example: Inspection is never completely effective, so appraisal costs stay high as long as the failure costs stay high.

Synset.Definition: any liability expected to be paid off in one year or less.
Synset.ILIDefinition: any liability expected to be paid off in one year or less.

Synset.Definition: an option where the buyer has the right to exercise at a set (always discretely spaced) number of times.
Synset.ILIDefinition: an option where the buyer has the right to exercise at a set (always discretely spaced) number of times.
Synset.Example: The Bermudan option is somewhat American and somewhat European—in terms of both option style and physical location.

Synset.Definition: the total revenue a company or project collects from sales divided by the number of units sold over a period of time.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the total revenue a company or project collects from sales divided by the number of units sold over a period of time.

Synset.Definition: account that records any surplus after the revaluation of assets.
Synset.ILIDefinition: account that records any surplus after the revaluation of assets.
Synset.Example: The increase in depreciation arising out of revaluation of fixed assets is debited to revaluation reserve and the normal depreciation to Profit and Loss account.

Synset.Definition: a second or subsequent investment in the same thing.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a second or subsequent investment in the same thing.

Synset.Definition: the price of a commodity such as a good or service in terms of another; i.e., the ratio of two prices.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the price of a commodity such as a good or service in terms of another; i.e., the ratio of two prices.
Synset.Example: Inflation makes it difficult for economic agents to immediately distinguish increases in the price of a good which are due to relative price changes from changes in the price which are due to inflation of prices.

Synset.Definition: a means to quantify the total cost of quality-related efforts and deficiencies.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a means to quantify the total cost of quality-related efforts and deficiencies.

Synset.Definition: a charge levied on products that are deemed harmful to the environment.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a charge levied on products that are deemed harmful to the environment.

Synset.Definition: tariff imposed on a foreign commercial entity as a form of reprisal.
Synset.ILIDefinition: tariff imposed on a foreign commercial entity as a form of reprisal.

Synset.Definition: a tax imposed by the government in special circumstances, intended to provide funding towards theoretically solidifying projects.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a tax imposed by the government in special circumstances, intended to provide funding towards theoretically solidifying projects.
Synset.Example: Up to €972 (€1,944 for married couples) annual income tax, no solidarity surcharge is levied.

Synset.Definition: a tax deduction for recovery of the cost of assets used in a business or for the production of income.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a tax deduction for recovery of the cost of assets used in a business or for the production of income.

Synset.Definition: liabilities that may be incurred by an entity depending on the outcome of a uncertain future event such as a court case.
Synset.ILIDefinition: liabilities that may be incurred by an entity depending on the outcome of a uncertain future event such as a court case.
Synset.Example: Examples of contingent liabilities include outstanding lawsuits, product warranty, claims against the company not acknowledged as debts, and so forth.

Synset.Definition: an allowance payable to employees who are given special assignments or perform additional duties.
Synset.ILIDefinition: an allowance payable to employees who are given special assignments or perform additional duties.

Synset.Definition: a stock that contains no ownership information and whose physical bearer is presumed to be the owner.
Synset.ILIDefinition: a stock that contains no ownership information and whose physical bearer is presumed to be the owner.
Synset.Example: Bearer shares are banned in some countries, because of their potential for abuse.

Synset.Definition: the cost of participating in a market.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the cost of participating in a market.
Synset.Example: The buyer of a used car faces a variety of different transaction costs: the costs of finding a car and determining the car's condition, the costs of negotiating a price with the seller, and the costs of ensuring that the seller delivers the car in the promised condition.
